p: Households without electricity tend to rely on biomass such as wood and charcoal to meet their energy needs [ 31, 32]. However, if people harvest the wood at a faster rate than trees can grow, the capacity of natural forests to contribute towards climate change mitigation will be diminished [ 9]. Trees are described as carbon sinks as they absorb carbon which causes greenhouse gasses [ 32]. Deforestation and desertification also have implications on water resources and food production due to erosion, and declining arable lands, respectively. Soil erosion can result in the transportation of top soil and sediments, which are rich in organic materials, nutrients, chemicals, and soil life, into water bodies, causing river siltation, water pollution, and in some instances, water eutrophication, which threaten aquatic life [ 24]. The loss of rich soil also affects food production by removing soil nutrients and degrading arable land [ 24].
